prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO76_CI21_850140
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO76 and CI21 line & 350mu rest frame continuum in 850140

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For highest possible continuum bandwidth and to cover the CO76 and CI21 at the same time we ask for the highest bandwidth configuration of the correlator. However, we aim for a velocity resolution better than delivered by the 250MHz resolution configuration. So we select the full-bandwidth, high resolution mode but with the maximum possible spectral binning to keep the data rate as low as possible.

We ask to undertake the Band 8 - non-standard observations in the most compact configuration available to keep the phase stability at a maximum. We aim for the C36-2 configuration in March 2016. During this time our sources are visible in the night (10h field). In of case good weather for high frequency observtions earlier in the year, the observations can be also carried out the in C36-1 configuration.

We have estimated the expected line and continuum intensities using our CO(2-1) flux density measured in PHIBSS2. For the continuum we have use a CO converions factor of Xco=0.8 and a gas to dust mass ratio of 150 to calculate the expected dust mass in the source. Assuming further a typical dust temperature of 35K yields the estimete used in this calculation. To predict the higher-J CO line intensities from the CO(2-1) we have considered two different excitation cases: 1) a case similar to the excitation shown in Fig 1 (center) and a lower excitation case where the case excitation is similar to the MW. The rms request for the CO(7-6) and CI(2-1) line is based on the expected CI(2-1) intensity in the low excitation case (similar to the situation we measure in zC406690), requireing that we will be able to detect CI(2-1) with a peak flux density of 3sigma (>4 for the integral). The CO(7-6) will remain undetected in that case. In the high excitation case both lines will be detected with higher sensitivity then indicated in this TE. The line widith of this target is 470 km/s, so a velocity resolution of 100 km/s is sufficient to resolve the line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO76_CI21_838696
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO76 and CI21 line & 350mu rest frame continuum in 838696

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The justification is the same as for the Band 8 observations of 850140.
The justification is the same as for the Band 8 observations of 850140.

The justification is mostly identical to the Band 8 observations of 850140. This source, however, as a significant narrower line width and your observations will not resolve the line profiles in the low excitation case. For the high excitation case the predicted line intensities go up by more than a factor of 2, so enabaling us to analyse also the line profile in that case.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO43 850140
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO43 line & 450mu rest frame continuum in 850140

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The justification is the same as for the Band 8 observations of 850140.
As we only aim to obtain integrated line intensities, we ask for observations in any of the two most compact configuration to keep the phase stabiity of at a maxiumum.

For the estimate of the CO(4-3) line intensity we used the same model as describe for the justification of the observing setup in Band 8 for 850140. The rms request for the CO(4-3) line is driven by the desire to detect this line even in the low excitation case. The continuum is expected to remain undetected for this part of the project.

As we only aim to obtain integrated line intensities, we ask for observations in any of the two most compact configuration to keep the phase stabiity of at a maxiumum.

The justification is mostly identical to the Band 7 observations of 850140. This source, however, as a significant narrower line width and your observations will not resolve the line profiles in the low excitation case. For the high excitation case the predicted line intensities go up by more than a factor of 2, so enabaling us to analyse also the line profile in that case.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent CO observations in normal main-sequence galaxies at high redshift have shown that their star formation efficiency is lower than in case of merger driven SMGs, more consistent with the star formation efficiency in local spiral galaxies. The picture that emerges from this studies is that SMGs form stars more rapidly because their gas clouds are more compressed so they churn more quickly through the available gas reservoir than the typical normal high-z disk galaxies. These differences in the physical conditions of the ISM are expected to affect the CO and CI line ratios. Our very first results from cycle 2 indeed show an unusual CI(2--1)/CO(7--6) line ratio, which indicates low gas densities in line with the expectation of diffuse gas in extended disks. A coherent picture of the gas excitation in main sequence systems, however, is missing so far. We here ask to continue our study of the gas excitation in main-sequence galaxies selected from the PHIBSS survey and to observe a small sample of z=0.7 galaxies. Our study aims to provide for the first time well characterized templates of the gas excitation in high redshift main-sequence galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
